        Our window.open()|moveTo()|moveBy()|resizeTo()|resizeBy() should never permit a placement to be offscreen or partly offscreen.<span class="line"><!---->Our window.open()|moveTo()|moveBy()|resizeTo()|resizeBy() should never permit a placement to be offscreen or partly offscreen.<!----></span><br>window.open() by default clamps placements to be entirely within the current screen's available space.<span class="line"><!---->window.open() by default clamps placements to be entirely within the current screen's available space.<!----></span><br>With the new window-placement permission, we permit placement on another screen's available space.<span class="line"><!---->With the new window-placement permission, we permit placement on another screen's available space.<!----></span><br>There are indeed also minimum size requirements.<span class="line"><!---->There are indeed also minimum size requirements.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        As dcheng@ mentioned, I'd suggest we apply similar (or identical) restrictions to extension windows being created.  I could see us being slightly more flexible (say, maybe >50% of the window needs to be visible?), but extensions should not be able to create entirely offscreen windows.<span class="line"><!---->As dcheng@ mentioned, I'd suggest we apply similar (or identical) restrictions to extension windows being created.  I could see us being slightly more flexible (say, maybe &gt;50% of the window needs to be visible?), but extensions should not be able to create entirely offscreen windows.<!----></span><br><br>avi@, msw@, if you can include any links to specs and/or code enforcement, it'd be helpful.<span class="line"><!---->avi@, msw@, if you can include any links to specs and/or code enforcement, it'd be helpful.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the pointers, msw@!  I think we'll want to do something conceptually similar, but slightly different than those.  In particular, the WebContents method says:<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the pointers, msw@!  I think we'll want to do something conceptually similar, but slightly different than those.  In particular, the WebContents method says:<!----></span><br><br>// The bounds may not extend<span class="line"><!---->// The bounds may not extend<!----></span><br>// outside a single screen's work area, and the |host| requires permission to<span class="line"><!---->// outside a single screen's work area, and the |host| requires permission to<!----></span><br>// specify bounds on a screen other than its current screen.<span class="line"><!---->// specify bounds on a screen other than its current screen.<!----></span><br><br>But I think both of these would be fine for extensions (and may well be relied upon for things like session managers).  But we should be able to use somewhat similar logic to tell if a window's requested bounds are beyond the full "screen" (which may be multiple displays).  One solution that comes to mind would be requiring >=50% of the window to be in a single display; however, I wonder if this would break valid use cases with multi-display setup (like three monitors side by side where an extension wants the window to be full-screen across all three).  msw@, do you know if Screen / Display have any handy methods that would help us determine whether enough of the window is on valid displays, or is the best way to just iterate over all displays in the screen to determine?<span class="line"><!---->But I think both of these would be fine for extensions (and may well be relied upon for things like session managers).  But we should be able to use somewhat similar logic to tell if a window's requested bounds are beyond the full "screen" (which may be multiple displays).  One solution that comes to mind would be requiring &gt;=50% of the window to be in a single display; however, I wonder if this would break valid use cases with multi-display setup (like three monitors side by side where an extension wants the window to be full-screen across all three).  msw@, do you know if Screen / Display have any handy methods that would help us determine whether enough of the window is on valid displays, or is the best way to just iterate over all displays in the screen to determine?<!----></span><br><br>emiliapaz@, do you think you have the bandwidth to work with msw@ to take this one on?<span class="line"><!---->emiliapaz@, do you think you have the bandwidth to work with msw@ to take this one on?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

        RE #12: Those use cases seem reasonable for a powerful extension (and maybe eventually for a powerful web platform API). You'll likely need to iterate over display::Screen::GetAllDisplays() to determine the overall on-screen portion of the requested window bounds. You might want to ensure that some portion of the window's titlebar is on screen too (if the window has a titlebar for identity, user controls and dragging, etc.). I'm happy to help with code review or other questions here.<span class="line"><!---->RE #12: Those use cases seem reasonable for a powerful extension (and maybe eventually for a powerful web platform API). You'll likely need to iterate over display::Screen::GetAllDisplays() to determine the overall on-screen portion of the requested window bounds. You might want to ensure that some portion of the window's titlebar is on screen too (if the window has a titlebar for identity, user controls and dragging, etc.). I'm happy to help with code review or other questions here.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Showing the popup only when it appears at least 50% on the current displays seems reasonable to me. The question then is, what happens if bounds do not intersect 50% with the displays? Do we a) leave the popup at its current position or b) get the closest display matching and adjust to fit (similar to [1])?<span class="line"><!---->Showing the popup only when it appears at least 50% on the current displays seems reasonable to me. The question then is, what happens if bounds do not intersect 50% with the displays? Do we a) leave the popup at its current position or b) get the closest display matching and adjust to fit (similar to [1])?<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

Low, just a few functions/tests conflicts around the added code<!----></span><br>3. <span class="line"><!---->3. <!----></span>https://crbug.com/1301203#c27<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1301203#c27" title="Security: Extension can move window off screen, user can interact with sensitive UI using keyboard without being aware"><!---->https://crbug.com/1301203#c27<!----></a><br>4. No, as per <span class="line"><!---->4. No, as per <!----></span>https://crbug.com/1301203#c27<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1301203#c27" title="Security: Extension can move window off screen, user can interact with sensitive UI using keyboard without being aware"><!---->https://crbug.com/1301203#c27<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

           issue<h3 class="medium-heading"><!----> issue</h3>
          
            Target project:<label for="targetProjectInput">Target project:</label>
            
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              
      
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }

            <div>
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          <div class="input-grid">

            <div>

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement.

        Email display settings<h2>Email display settings</h2>

        There is a setting<a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.<p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.<p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to get
        involved<a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.<p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="privacyDialog" forced="">
        <h2>Email display settings</h2>

        <p>There is a <a href="/hosting/settings">setting</a> to control how
        your email address appears on comments and issues that you post.</p>

        <p>Project members will always see your full email address.  By
        default, other users who visit the site will see an
        abbreviated version of your email address.</p>

        <p>If you do not wish your email address to be shared, there
        are other ways to <a href="http://www.chromium.org/getting-involved">get
        involved</a> in the community.  To report a problem when using
        the Chrome browser, you may use the "Report an issue..."  item
        on the "Help" menu.</p>


        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </chops-dialog>

      
      
        
          <slot></slot>
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      <dialog class="dialog" role="dialog">
        <div class="dialog-content">
          <slot></slot>
        </div>
      </dialog>
    
        This site hosts public issues in public projects<h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.<p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.<p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        
          
      
        <slot></slot>
      <button>
        <slot></slot>
      </button>
    
            Got it
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      <chops-dialog id="corpModeDialog" forced="">
        <h2>This site hosts public issues in public projects</h2>

        <p>Unlike our internal issue tracker, this site makes most
        issues public, unless the issue is labeled with a Restrict-View-*
        label, such as Restrict-View-Google.</p>

        <p>Components are not used for permissions.  And, regardless of
        restriction labels, the issue reporter, owner,
        and Cc'd users may always view the issue.</p>

        

        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button>
            Got it
          </chops-button>

        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Feb 27, 2022)
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Feb 27, 2022)
      </option>
    
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Feb 27, 2022)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">
          <!---->
      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Feb 27, 2022)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>An extension can create or move any window outside of the screen, and the window can still receive keyboard input. This can hide user interactions using keyboard input with sensitive browser UI and web pages. I've identified a myriad of affected areas, and there are potentially other areas which may have similar or greater severity impacts. I've verified on Windows + Chrome OS. The extension does not require any permissions.<span class="line"><!---->An extension can create or move any window outside of the screen, and the window can still receive keyboard input. This can hide user interactions using keyboard input with sensitive browser UI and web pages. I've identified a myriad of affected areas, and there are potentially other areas which may have similar or greater severity impacts. I've verified on Windows + Chrome OS. The extension does not require any permissions.<!----></span><br><br>On Windows, for most scenarios, the window position must be just off screen which is sufficient to completely hide the window from the user. For the screen share dialog, external protocol dialog, and possibly other dialogs, the window position does not matter (we can set coordinates thousands of pixels off screen).<span class="line"><!---->On Windows, for most scenarios, the window position must be just off screen which is sufficient to completely hide the window from the user. For the screen share dialog, external protocol dialog, and possibly other dialogs, the window position does not matter (we can set coordinates thousands of pixels off screen).<!----></span><br><br>On Chrome OS, the window position does not matter (we can set coordinates thousands of pixels off screen).<span class="line"><!---->On Chrome OS, the window position does not matter (we can set coordinates thousands of pixels off screen).<!----></span><br><br>Verified impacts ("without user awareness" implied unless otherwise specified):<span class="line"><!---->Verified impacts ("without user awareness" implied unless otherwise specified):<!----></span><br><br>* Screen share dialog: Share screen with 3 keypresses. Only mitigation is the small widget/notification after sharing that says <span class="line"><!---->* Screen share dialog: Share screen with 3 keypresses. Only mitigation is the small widget/notification after sharing that says <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com"><!---->example.com<!----></a> is sharing your screen".<span class="line"><!----> is sharing your screen".<!----></span><br><br>* Permssion prompts: Allow permission for origin with 3 keypresses (4 on ChromeOS). e.g. camera, microphone, location, etc.<span class="line"><!---->* Permssion prompts: Allow permission for origin with 3 keypresses (4 on ChromeOS). e.g. camera, microphone, location, etc.<!----></span><br><br>* Autofill: Open autofill prompt, select item, and fill autofill entry into page with 2 keypresses. The browser fills in multiple fields at once with this interaction. Can obtain name, address, and credit card info.<span class="line"><!---->* Autofill: Open autofill prompt, select item, and fill autofill entry into page with 2 keypresses. The browser fills in multiple fields at once with this interaction. Can obtain name, address, and credit card info.<!----></span><br><br>* Payment request: Complete payment request with a few keypresses (as few as 2 keypresses; depends on payment flow).<span class="line"><!---->* Payment request: Complete payment request with a few keypresses (as few as 2 keypresses; depends on payment flow).<!----></span><br><br>* Web pages: Interact with any page. Can perform sensitive actions on logged-in or intranet pages.<span class="line"><!---->* Web pages: Interact with any page. Can perform sensitive actions on logged-in or intranet pages.<!----></span><br><br>* chrome:// pages: Interact with any chrome:// page.<span class="line"><!---->* chrome:// pages: Interact with any chrome:// page.<!----></span><br>  * chrome://settings/security contains settings related to Safe Browsing, and other chrome://settings page may have sensitive settings.<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://settings/security contains settings related to Safe Browsing, and other chrome://settings page may have sensitive settings.<!----></span><br>  * chrome://flags/ can toggle features which may affect security with 3 keypresses.<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://flags/ can toggle features which may affect security with 3 keypresses.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>* External protocols: Allow website to open app with 2 keypresses. Also can enable "always allow {origin} to open links of this type..." to allow multi-step or future drive-by external protocol launches.<span class="line"><!---->* External protocols: Allow website to open app with 2 keypresses. Also can enable "always allow {origin} to open links of this type..." to allow multi-step or future drive-by external protocol launches.<!----></span><br><br>* Downloads: Open downloads in download bar with 2 keypresses, or in chrome://downloads with a few keypresses (does not bypass any OS-level protection)<span class="line"><!---->* Downloads: Open downloads in download bar with 2 keypresses, or in chrome://downloads with a few keypresses (does not bypass any OS-level protection)<!----></span><br><br>* Pointer lock: Obtain pointer lock without notification. Might be useful when combined with other bugs.<span class="line"><!---->* Pointer lock: Obtain pointer lock without notification. Might be useful when combined with other bugs.<!----></span><br><br>* Copy/paste: Can obtain page content with Ctrl+A, Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V from most web pages or chrome:// pages. This is an issue if the page has sensitive content.<span class="line"><!---->* Copy/paste: Can obtain page content with Ctrl+A, Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V from most web pages or chrome:// pages. This is an issue if the page has sensitive content.<!----></span><br>  * chrome://predictors/<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://predictors/<!----></span><br>  * chrome://local-state/ (os_crypt.encrypted_key?)<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://local-state/ (os_crypt.encrypted_key?)<!----></span><br>  * chrome://prefs-internals/ (gaia, sync entries?)<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://prefs-internals/ (gaia, sync entries?)<!----></span><br>  * And others which provide potentially sensitive info such as frequent sites, recent sites/URLs, installed extensions, etc.<span class="line"><!---->  * And others which provide potentially sensitive info such as frequent sites, recent sites/URLs, installed extensions, etc.<!----></span><br><br>Mitigated impact:<span class="line"><!---->Mitigated impact:<!----></span><br><br>* Installing extension from Chrome Web Store requires a lot of keypresses (at least 7), and the confirmation dialog always appears on screen even if window is off screen.<span class="line"><!---->* Installing extension from Chrome Web Store requires a lot of keypresses (at least 7), and the confirmation dialog always appears on screen even if window is off screen.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 98.0.4758.102 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), 101.0.4912.0 Canary<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 98.0.4758.102 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), 101.0.4912.0 Canary<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 Version 20H2 (Build 19042.1526)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 Version 20H2 (Build 19042.1526)<!----></span><br><br>Chrome Version: 98.0.4758.107 Stable, 93.0.4577.85 Stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 98.0.4758.107 Stable, 93.0.4577.85 Stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Chrome OS 14388.61.0, 14092.57.0<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Chrome OS 14388.61.0, 14092.57.0<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>Initial setup:<span class="line"><!---->Initial setup:<!----></span><br>1. Install attached extension: manifest.json + bg.js<span class="line"><!---->1. Install attached extension: manifest.json + bg.js<!----></span><br><br>All PoC scenarios:<span class="line"><!---->All PoC scenarios:<!----></span><br>1. Set the scenario variable in bg.js.<span class="line"><!---->1. Set the scenario variable in bg.js.<!----></span><br>Available scenarios: permission, screenshare, download, payment, autofill, autofill-creditcard, externalprotocol, flags, extension<span class="line"><!---->Available scenarios: permission, screenshare, download, payment, autofill, autofill-creditcard, externalprotocol, flags, extension<!----></span><br>2. Reload the extension.<span class="line"><!---->2. Reload the extension.<!----></span><br>3. Follow instructions shown in the extension-created tab.<span class="line"><!---->3. Follow instructions shown in the extension-created tab.<!----></span><br>4. Once the extension reveals the off-screen window, observe the interaction results.<span class="line"><!---->4. Once the extension reveals the off-screen window, observe the interaction results.<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Window is off screen and not visible to user. Off-screen window accepts keyboard input in sensitive browser UI and web pages.<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Window is off screen and not visible to user. Off-screen window accepts keyboard input in sensitive browser UI and web pages.<!----></span><br>Expected: Sensitive browser UI is always visible to user, or window does not accept keyboard input when not properly visible to user.<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Sensitive browser UI is always visible to user, or window does not accept keyboard input when not properly visible to user.<!----></span><br><br>Optional:<span class="line"><!---->Optional:<!----></span><br>You can try different window positions to see that on Windows most scenarios don't work with larger off-screen positions.<span class="line"><!---->You can try different window positions to see that on Windows most scenarios don't work with larger off-screen positions.<!----></span><br>To observe real-time keyboard input interaction results, you can keep the window on screen by commenting-out the windows.update() call. This is also useful for debugging or developing new scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->To observe real-time keyboard input interaction results, you can keep the window on screen by commenting-out the windows.update() call. This is also useful for debugging or developing new scenarios.<!----></span><br>I've verified the other scenarios in internal PoCs. You can update the attached PoC to test the other scenarios if you'd like.<span class="line"><!---->I've verified the other scenarios in internal PoCs. You can update the attached PoC to test the other scenarios if you'd like.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz <<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz &lt;<!----></span>https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://AlesandroOrtiz.com"><!---->https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Additional verified impact:<span class="line"><!---->Additional verified impact:<!----></span><br>* XSS via bookmark + address bar: Run attacker-provided JavaScript on any web page with 4 or 6 keypresses.<span class="line"><!---->* XSS via bookmark + address bar: Run attacker-provided JavaScript on any web page with 4 or 6 keypresses.<!----></span><br><br>As described in <span class="line"><!---->As described in <!----></span>issue 1301874<span class="line"><!---->issue 1301874<!----></span>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>an extension with only bookmarks permission can create or update a bookmark with a javascript: URL (this is supported behavior). A user can also run a javascript: bookmark from the address bar (probably unsafe). That issue uses several techniques to convince the user to select the malicious bookmark in a fully-visible window with minimal suspicion (unsafe).<span class="line"><!---->an extension with only bookmarks permission can create or update a bookmark with a javascript: URL (this is supported behavior). A user can also run a javascript: bookmark from the address bar (probably unsafe). That issue uses several techniques to convince the user to select the malicious bookmark in a fully-visible window with minimal suspicion (unsafe).<!----></span><br><br>However, we can get rid of all the stealth techniques from <span class="line"><!---->However, we can get rid of all the stealth techniques from <!----></span>issue 1301874<span class="line"><!---->issue 1301874<!----></span> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> replace them with an off-screen window to achieve the same result. This is easier to perform since the user has no awareness whatsoever, while in <span class="line"><!----> replace them with an off-screen window to achieve the same result. This is easier to perform since the user has no awareness whatsoever, while in <!----></span>issue 1301874<span class="line"><!---->issue 1301874<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>there's some user awareness.<span class="line"><!---->there's some user awareness.<!----></span><br><br>I've attached a separate PoC extension which uses the bookmarks permission, but otherwise is roughly the same as the PoC from <span class="line"><!---->I've attached a separate PoC extension which uses the bookmarks permission, but otherwise is roughly the same as the PoC from <!----></span>#c0<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c0"><!---->#c0<!----></a>. I've also attached the updated offscreen.html and offscreen-instructions.html to include additional logic for this PoC. (I've also updated the hosted versions.)<span class="line"><!---->. I've also attached the updated offscreen.html and offscreen-instructions.html to include additional logic for this PoC. (I've also updated the hosted versions.)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<span class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></span><br>Initial setup:<span class="line"><!---->Initial setup:<!----></span><br>1. Install attached extension: manifest-offscreen-bookmark-xss.json + bg-offscreen-bookmark-xss.js. Rename the manifest file to manifest.json.<span class="line"><!---->1. Install attached extension: manifest-offscreen-bookmark-xss.json + bg-offscreen-bookmark-xss.js. Rename the manifest file to manifest.json.<!----></span><br><br>Off-screen window bookmark XSS scenario:<span class="line"><!---->Off-screen window bookmark XSS scenario:<!----></span><br>1. Reload the extension to start the PoC. The next steps are also shown as instructions in the extension-created tab.<span class="line"><!---->1. Reload the extension to start the PoC. The next steps are also shown as instructions in the extension-created tab.<!----></span><br>2. Press Tab, Tab, Tab to focus on the address bar.<span class="line"><!---->2. Press Tab, Tab, Tab to focus on the address bar.<!----></span><br>3. Press Ctrl+V to paste the bookmark name (written into clipboard by attacker page).<span class="line"><!---->3. Press Ctrl+V to paste the bookmark name (written into clipboard by attacker page).<!----></span><br>4. Press Tab to select the bookmark item in the address bar dropdown.<span class="line"><!---->4. Press Tab to select the bookmark item in the address bar dropdown.<!----></span><br>5. Press Enter to navigate the bookmark item.<span class="line"><!---->5. Press Enter to navigate the bookmark item.<!----></span><br>6. Once the extension reveals the off-screen window, observe the interaction results.<span class="line"><!---->6. Once the extension reveals the off-screen window, observe the interaction results.<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Same as <span class="line"><!---->Observed: Same as <!----></span>#c0<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c0"><!---->#c0<!----></a>. In this specific scenario, bookmark runs JavaScript payload on target origin.<span class="line"><!---->. In this specific scenario, bookmark runs JavaScript payload on target origin.<!----></span><br>Expected: Same as <span class="line"><!---->Expected: Same as <!----></span>#c0<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c0"><!---->#c0<!----></a>. In this specific scenario, bookmark does not run JavaScript payload.<span class="line"><!---->. In this specific scenario, bookmark does not run JavaScript payload.<!----></span><br><br>(Note to self: Avoid disclosing this crbug before <span class="line"><!---->(Note to self: Avoid disclosing this crbug before <!----></span>issue 1301874<span class="line"><!---->issue 1301874<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>since this comment includes details of the other crbug.)<span class="line"><!---->since this comment includes details of the other crbug.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Our window.open()|moveTo()|moveBy()|resizeTo()|resizeBy() should never permit a placement to be offscreen or partly offscreen.<span class="line"><!---->Our window.open()|moveTo()|moveBy()|resizeTo()|resizeBy() should never permit a placement to be offscreen or partly offscreen.<!----></span><br>window.open() by default clamps placements to be entirely within the current screen's available space.<span class="line"><!---->window.open() by default clamps placements to be entirely within the current screen's available space.<!----></span><br>With the new window-placement permission, we permit placement on another screen's available space.<span class="line"><!---->With the new window-placement permission, we permit placement on another screen's available space.<!----></span><br>There are indeed also minimum size requirements.<span class="line"><!---->There are indeed also minimum size requirements.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        As dcheng@ mentioned, I'd suggest we apply similar (or identical) restrictions to extension windows being created. I could see us being slightly more flexible (say, maybe &gt;50% of the window needs to be visible?), but extensions should not be able to create entirely offscreen windows.<!----></span><br><br>avi@, msw@, if you can include any links to specs and/or code enforcement, it'd be helpful.<span class="line"><!---->avi@, msw@, if you can include any links to specs and/or code enforcement, it'd be helpful.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the pointers, msw@!  I think we'll want to do something conceptually similar, but slightly different than those.  In particular, the WebContents method says:<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the pointers, msw@!  I think we'll want to do something conceptually similar, but slightly different than those.  In particular, the WebContents method says:<!----></span><br><br>// The bounds may not extend<span class="line"><!---->// The bounds may not extend<!----></span><br>// outside a single screen's work area, and the |host| requires permission to<span class="line"><!---->// outside a single screen's work area, and the |host| requires permission to<!----></span><br>// specify bounds on a screen other than its current screen.<span class="line"><!---->// specify bounds on a screen other than its current screen.<!----></span><br><br>But I think both of these would be fine for extensions (and may well be relied upon for things like session managers).  But we should be able to use somewhat similar logic to tell if a window's requested bounds are beyond the full "screen" (which may be multiple displays).  One solution that comes to mind would be requiring >=50% of the window to be in a single display; however, I wonder if this would break valid use cases with multi-display setup (like three monitors side by side where an extension wants the window to be full-screen across all three).  msw@, do you know if Screen / Display have any handy methods that would help us determine whether enough of the window is on valid displays, or is the best way to just iterate over all displays in the screen to determine?<span class="line"><!---->But I think both of these would be fine for extensions (and may well be relied upon for things like session managers).  But we should be able to use somewhat similar logic to tell if a window's requested bounds are beyond the full "screen" (which may be multiple displays).  One solution that comes to mind would be requiring &gt;=50% of the window to be in a single display; however, I wonder if this would break valid use cases with multi-display setup (like three monitors side by side where an extension wants the window to be full-screen across all three).  msw@, do you know if Screen / Display have any handy methods that would help us determine whether enough of the window is on valid displays, or is the best way to just iterate over all displays in the screen to determine?<!----></span><br><br>emiliapaz@, do you think you have the bandwidth to work with msw@ to take this one on?<span class="line"><!---->emiliapaz@, do you think you have the bandwidth to work with msw@ to take this one on?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        RE #12: Those use cases seem reasonable for a powerful extension (and maybe eventually for a powerful web platform API). You'll likely need to iterate over display::Screen::GetAllDisplays() to determine the overall on-screen portion of the requested window bounds. You might want to ensure that some portion of the window's titlebar is on screen too (if the window has a titlebar for identity, user controls and dragging, etc.). I'm happy to help with code review or other questions here.<span class="line"><!---->RE #12: Those use cases seem reasonable for a powerful extension (and maybe eventually for a powerful web platform API). You'll likely need to iterate over display::Screen::GetAllDisplays() to determine the overall on-screen portion of the requested window bounds. You might want to ensure that some portion of the window's titlebar is on screen too (if the window has a titlebar for identity, user controls and dragging, etc.). I'm happy to help with code review or other questions here.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        Showing the popup only when it appears at least 50% on the current displays seems reasonable to me. The question then is, what happens if bounds do not intersect 50% with the displays? Do we a) leave the popup at its current position or b) get the closest display matching and adjust to fit (similar to [1])?<span class="line"><!---->Showing the popup only when it appears at least 50% on the current displays seems reasonable to me. The question then is, what happens if bounds do not intersect 50% with the displays? Do we a) leave the popup at its current position or b) get the closest display matching and adjust to fit (similar to [1])?<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Issue 1301203: Security: Extension can move window off screen, user can interact with sensitive UI using keyboard without being aware

        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Feb 27, 2022)
      <option value="0" selected="">

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>An extension can create or move any window outside of the screen, and the window can still receive keyboard input. This can hide user interactions using keyboard input with sensitive browser UI and web pages. I've identified a myriad of affected areas, and there are potentially other areas which may have similar or greater severity impacts. I've verified on Windows + Chrome OS. The extension does not require any permissions.<span class="line"><!---->An extension can create or move any window outside of the screen, and the window can still receive keyboard input. This can hide user interactions using keyboard input with sensitive browser UI and web pages. I've identified a myriad of affected areas, and there are potentially other areas which may have similar or greater severity impacts. I've verified on Windows + Chrome OS. The extension does not require any permissions.<!----></span><br><br>On Windows, for most scenarios, the window position must be just off screen which is sufficient to completely hide the window from the user. For the screen share dialog, external protocol dialog, and possibly other dialogs, the window position does not matter (we can set coordinates thousands of pixels off screen).<span class="line"><!---->On Windows, for most scenarios, the window position must be just off screen which is sufficient to completely hide the window from the user. For the screen share dialog, external protocol dialog, and possibly other dialogs, the window position does not matter (we can set coordinates thousands of pixels off screen).<!----></span><br><br>On Chrome OS, the window position does not matter (we can set coordinates thousands of pixels off screen).<span class="line"><!---->On Chrome OS, the window position does not matter (we can set coordinates thousands of pixels off screen).<!----></span><br><br>Verified impacts ("without user awareness" implied unless otherwise specified):<span class="line"><!---->Verified impacts ("without user awareness" implied unless otherwise specified):<!----></span><br><br>* Screen share dialog: Share screen with 3 keypresses. Only mitigation is the small widget/notification after sharing that says <span class="line"><!---->* Screen share dialog: Share screen with 3 keypresses. Only mitigation is the small widget/notification after sharing that says <!----></span>"<span class="line"><!---->"<!----></span>example.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://example.com"><!---->example.com<!----></a> is sharing your screen".<span class="line"><!----> is sharing your screen".<!----></span><br><br>* Permssion prompts: Allow permission for origin with 3 keypresses (4 on ChromeOS). e.g. camera, microphone, location, etc.<span class="line"><!---->* Permssion prompts: Allow permission for origin with 3 keypresses (4 on ChromeOS). e.g. camera, microphone, location, etc.<!----></span><br><br>* Autofill: Open autofill prompt, select item, and fill autofill entry into page with 2 keypresses. The browser fills in multiple fields at once with this interaction. Can obtain name, address, and credit card info.<span class="line"><!---->* Autofill: Open autofill prompt, select item, and fill autofill entry into page with 2 keypresses. The browser fills in multiple fields at once with this interaction. Can obtain name, address, and credit card info.<!----></span><br><br>* Payment request: Complete payment request with a few keypresses (as few as 2 keypresses; depends on payment flow).<span class="line"><!---->* Payment request: Complete payment request with a few keypresses (as few as 2 keypresses; depends on payment flow).<!----></span><br><br>* Web pages: Interact with any page. Can perform sensitive actions on logged-in or intranet pages.<span class="line"><!---->* Web pages: Interact with any page. Can perform sensitive actions on logged-in or intranet pages.<!----></span><br><br>* chrome:// pages: Interact with any chrome:// page.<span class="line"><!---->* chrome:// pages: Interact with any chrome:// page.<!----></span><br>  * chrome://settings/security contains settings related to Safe Browsing, and other chrome://settings page may have sensitive settings.<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://settings/security contains settings related to Safe Browsing, and other chrome://settings page may have sensitive settings.<!----></span><br>  * chrome://flags/ can toggle features which may affect security with 3 keypresses.<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://flags/ can toggle features which may affect security with 3 keypresses.<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span><br>* External protocols: Allow website to open app with 2 keypresses. Also can enable "always allow {origin} to open links of this type..." to allow multi-step or future drive-by external protocol launches.<span class="line"><!---->* External protocols: Allow website to open app with 2 keypresses. Also can enable "always allow {origin} to open links of this type..." to allow multi-step or future drive-by external protocol launches.<!----></span><br><br>* Downloads: Open downloads in download bar with 2 keypresses, or in chrome://downloads with a few keypresses (does not bypass any OS-level protection)<span class="line"><!---->* Downloads: Open downloads in download bar with 2 keypresses, or in chrome://downloads with a few keypresses (does not bypass any OS-level protection)<!----></span><br><br>* Pointer lock: Obtain pointer lock without notification. Might be useful when combined with other bugs.<span class="line"><!---->* Pointer lock: Obtain pointer lock without notification. Might be useful when combined with other bugs.<!----></span><br><br>* Copy/paste: Can obtain page content with Ctrl+A, Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V from most web pages or chrome:// pages. This is an issue if the page has sensitive content.<span class="line"><!---->* Copy/paste: Can obtain page content with Ctrl+A, Ctrl+C, Ctrl+V from most web pages or chrome:// pages. This is an issue if the page has sensitive content.<!----></span><br>  * chrome://predictors/<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://predictors/<!----></span><br>  * chrome://local-state/ (os_crypt.encrypted_key?)<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://local-state/ (os_crypt.encrypted_key?)<!----></span><br>  * chrome://prefs-internals/ (gaia, sync entries?)<span class="line"><!---->  * chrome://prefs-internals/ (gaia, sync entries?)<!----></span><br>  * And others which provide potentially sensitive info such as frequent sites, recent sites/URLs, installed extensions, etc.<span class="line"><!---->  * And others which provide potentially sensitive info such as frequent sites, recent sites/URLs, installed extensions, etc.<!----></span><br><br>Mitigated impact:<span class="line"><!---->Mitigated impact:<!----></span><br><br>* Installing extension from Chrome Web Store requires a lot of keypresses (at least 7), and the confirmation dialog always appears on screen even if window is off screen.<span class="line"><!---->* Installing extension from Chrome Web Store requires a lot of keypresses (at least 7), and the confirmation dialog always appears on screen even if window is off screen.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 98.0.4758.102 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), 101.0.4912.0 Canary<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 98.0.4758.102 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), 101.0.4912.0 Canary<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 Version 20H2 (Build 19042.1526)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 Version 20H2 (Build 19042.1526)<!----></span><br><br>Chrome Version: 98.0.4758.107 Stable, 93.0.4577.85 Stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 98.0.4758.107 Stable, 93.0.4577.85 Stable<!----></span><br>Operating System: Chrome OS 14388.61.0, 14092.57.0<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Chrome OS 14388.61.0, 14092.57.0<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>Initial setup:<span class="line"><!---->Initial setup:<!----></span><br>1. Install attached extension: manifest.json + bg.js<span class="line"><!---->1. Install attached extension: manifest.json + bg.js<!----></span><br><br>All PoC scenarios:<span class="line"><!---->All PoC scenarios:<!----></span><br>1. Set the scenario variable in bg.js.<span class="line"><!---->1. Set the scenario variable in bg.js.<!----></span><br>Available scenarios: permission, screenshare, download, payment, autofill, autofill-creditcard, externalprotocol, flags, extension<span class="line"><!---->Available scenarios: permission, screenshare, download, payment, autofill, autofill-creditcard, externalprotocol, flags, extension<!----></span><br>2. Reload the extension.<span class="line"><!---->2. Reload the extension.<!----></span><br>3. Follow instructions shown in the extension-created tab.<span class="line"><!---->3. Follow instructions shown in the extension-created tab.<!----></span><br>4. Once the extension reveals the off-screen window, observe the interaction results.<span class="line"><!---->4. Once the extension reveals the off-screen window, observe the interaction results.<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Window is off screen and not visible to user. Off-screen window accepts keyboard input in sensitive browser UI and web pages.<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Window is off screen and not visible to user. Off-screen window accepts keyboard input in sensitive browser UI and web pages.<!----></span><br>Expected: Sensitive browser UI is always visible to user, or window does not accept keyboard input when not properly visible to user.<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Sensitive browser UI is always visible to user, or window does not accept keyboard input when not properly visible to user.<!----></span><br><br>Optional:<span class="line"><!---->Optional:<!----></span><br>You can try different window positions to see that on Windows most scenarios don't work with larger off-screen positions.<span class="line"><!---->You can try different window positions to see that on Windows most scenarios don't work with larger off-screen positions.<!----></span><br>To observe real-time keyboard input interaction results, you can keep the window on screen by commenting-out the windows.update() call. This is also useful for debugging or developing new scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->To observe real-time keyboard input interaction results, you can keep the window on screen by commenting-out the windows.update() call. This is also useful for debugging or developing new scenarios.<!----></span><br>I've verified the other scenarios in internal PoCs. You can update the attached PoC to test the other scenarios if you'd like.<span class="line"><!---->I've verified the other scenarios in internal PoCs. You can update the attached PoC to test the other scenarios if you'd like.<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz <<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz &lt;<!----></span>https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://AlesandroOrtiz.com"><!---->https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Additional verified impact:<span class="line"><!---->Additional verified impact:<!----></span><br>* XSS via bookmark + address bar: Run attacker-provided JavaScript on any web page with 4 or 6 keypresses.<span class="line"><!---->* XSS via bookmark + address bar: Run attacker-provided JavaScript on any web page with 4 or 6 keypresses.<!----></span><br><br>As described in <span class="line"><!---->As described in <!----></span>issue 1301874<span class="line"><!---->issue 1301874<!----></span>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>an extension with only bookmarks permission can create or update a bookmark with a javascript: URL (this is supported behavior). A user can also run a javascript: bookmark from the address bar (probably unsafe). That issue uses several techniques to convince the user to select the malicious bookmark in a fully-visible window with minimal suspicion (unsafe).<span class="line"><!---->an extension with only bookmarks permission can create or update a bookmark with a javascript: URL (this is supported behavior). A user can also run a javascript: bookmark from the address bar (probably unsafe). That issue uses several techniques to convince the user to select the malicious bookmark in a fully-visible window with minimal suspicion (unsafe).<!----></span><br><br>However, we can get rid of all the stealth techniques from <span class="line"><!---->However, we can get rid of all the stealth techniques from <!----></span>issue 1301874<span class="line"><!---->issue 1301874<!----></span> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> replace them with an off-screen window to achieve the same result. This is easier to perform since the user has no awareness whatsoever, while in <span class="line"><!----> replace them with an off-screen window to achieve the same result. This is easier to perform since the user has no awareness whatsoever, while in <!----></span>issue 1301874<span class="line"><!---->issue 1301874<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>there's some user awareness.<span class="line"><!---->there's some user awareness.<!----></span><br><br>I've attached a separate PoC extension which uses the bookmarks permission, but otherwise is roughly the same as the PoC from <span class="line"><!---->I've attached a separate PoC extension which uses the bookmarks permission, but otherwise is roughly the same as the PoC from <!----></span>#c0<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c0"><!---->#c0<!----></a>. I've also attached the updated offscreen.html and offscreen-instructions.html to include additional logic for this PoC. (I've also updated the hosted versions.)<span class="line"><!---->. I've also attached the updated offscreen.html and offscreen-instructions.html to include additional logic for this PoC. (I've also updated the hosted versions.)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<span class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></span><br>Initial setup:<span class="line"><!---->Initial setup:<!----></span><br>1. Install attached extension: manifest-offscreen-bookmark-xss.json + bg-offscreen-bookmark-xss.js. Rename the manifest file to manifest.json.<span class="line"><!---->1. Install attached extension: manifest-offscreen-bookmark-xss.json + bg-offscreen-bookmark-xss.js. Rename the manifest file to manifest.json.<!----></span><br><br>Off-screen window bookmark XSS scenario:<span class="line"><!---->Off-screen window bookmark XSS scenario:<!----></span><br>1. Reload the extension to start the PoC. The next steps are also shown as instructions in the extension-created tab.<span class="line"><!---->1. Reload the extension to start the PoC. The next steps are also shown as instructions in the extension-created tab.<!----></span><br>2. Press Tab, Tab, Tab to focus on the address bar.<span class="line"><!---->2. Press Tab, Tab, Tab to focus on the address bar.<!----></span><br>3. Press Ctrl+V to paste the bookmark name (written into clipboard by attacker page).<span class="line"><!---->3. Press Ctrl+V to paste the bookmark name (written into clipboard by attacker page).<!----></span><br>4. Press Tab to select the bookmark item in the address bar dropdown.<span class="line"><!---->4. Press Tab to select the bookmark item in the address bar dropdown.<!----></span><br>5. Press Enter to navigate the bookmark item.<span class="line"><!---->5. Press Enter to navigate the bookmark item.<!----></span><br>6. Once the extension reveals the off-screen window, observe the interaction results.<span class="line"><!---->6. Once the extension reveals the off-screen window, observe the interaction results.<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Same as <span class="line"><!---->Observed: Same as <!----></span>#c0<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c0"><!---->#c0<!----></a>. In this specific scenario, bookmark runs JavaScript payload on target origin.<span class="line"><!---->. In this specific scenario, bookmark runs JavaScript payload on target origin.<!----></span><br>Expected: Same as <span class="line"><!---->Expected: Same as <!----></span>#c0<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c0"><!---->#c0<!----></a>. In this specific scenario, bookmark does not run JavaScript payload.<span class="line"><!---->. In this specific scenario, bookmark does not run JavaScript payload.<!----></span><br><br>(Note to self: Avoid disclosing this crbug before <span class="line"><!---->(Note to self: Avoid disclosing this crbug before <!----></span>issue 1301874<span class="line"><!---->issue 1301874<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>since this comment includes details of the other crbug.)<span class="line"><!---->since this comment includes details of the other crbug.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Our window.open()|moveTo()|moveBy()|resizeTo()|resizeBy() should never permit a placement to be offscreen or partly offscreen.<span class="line"><!---->Our window.open()|moveTo()|moveBy()|resizeTo()|resizeBy() should never permit a placement to be offscreen or partly offscreen.<!----></span><br>window.open() by default clamps placements to be entirely within the current screen's available space.<span class="line"><!---->window.open() by default clamps placements to be entirely within the current screen's available space.<!----></span><br>With the new window-placement permission, we permit placement on another screen's available space.<span class="line"><!---->With the new window-placement permission, we permit placement on another screen's available space.<!----></span><br>There are indeed also minimum size requirements.<span class="line"><!---->There are indeed also minimum size requirements.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        As dcheng@ mentioned, I'd suggest we apply similar (or identical) restrictions to extension windows being created.  I could see us being slightly more flexible (say, maybe >50% of the window needs to be visible?), but extensions should not be able to create entirely offscreen windows.<span class="line"><!---->As dcheng@ mentioned, I'd suggest we apply similar (or identical) restrictions to extension windows being created.  I could see us being slightly more flexible (say, maybe &gt;50% of the window needs to be visible?), but extensions should not be able to create entirely offscreen windows.<!----></span><br><br>avi@, msw@, if you can include any links to specs and/or code enforcement, it'd be helpful.<span class="line"><!---->avi@, msw@, if you can include any links to specs and/or code enforcement, it'd be helpful.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        Thanks for the pointers, msw@!  I think we'll want to do something conceptually similar, but slightly different than those.  In particular, the WebContents method says:<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the pointers, msw@!  I think we'll want to do something conceptually similar, but slightly different than those.  In particular, the WebContents method says:<!----></span><br><br>// The bounds may not extend<span class="line"><!---->// The bounds may not extend<!----></span><br>// outside a single screen's work area, and the |host| requires permission to<span class="line"><!---->// outside a single screen's work area, and the |host| requires permission to<!----></span><br>// specify bounds on a screen other than its current screen.<span class="line"><!---->// specify bounds on a screen other than its current screen.<!----></span><br><br>But I think both of these would be fine for extensions (and may well be relied upon for things like session managers).  But we should be able to use somewhat similar logic to tell if a window's requested bounds are beyond the full "screen" (which may be multiple displays).  One solution that comes to mind would be requiring >=50% of the window to be in a single display; however, I wonder if this would break valid use cases with multi-display setup (like three monitors side by side where an extension wants the window to be full-screen across all three).  msw@, do you know if Screen / Display have any handy methods that would help us determine whether enough of the window is on valid displays, or is the best way to just iterate over all displays in the screen to determine?<span class="line"><!---->But I think both of these would be fine for extensions (and may well be relied upon for things like session managers).  But we should be able to use somewhat similar logic to tell if a window's requested bounds are beyond the full "screen" (which may be multiple displays).  One solution that comes to mind would be requiring &gt;=50% of the window to be in a single display; however, I wonder if this would break valid use cases with multi-display setup (like three monitors side by side where an extension wants the window to be full-screen across all three).  msw@, do you know if Screen / Display have any handy methods that would help us determine whether enough of the window is on valid displays, or is the best way to just iterate over all displays in the screen to determine?<!----></span><br><br>emiliapaz@, do you think you have the bandwidth to work with msw@ to take this one on?<span class="line"><!---->emiliapaz@, do you think you have the bandwidth to work with msw@ to take this one on?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        RE #12: Those use cases seem reasonable for a powerful extension (and maybe eventually for a powerful web platform API). You'll likely need to iterate over display::Screen::GetAllDisplays() to determine the overall on-screen portion of the requested window bounds. You might want to ensure that some portion of the window's titlebar is on screen too (if the window has a titlebar for identity, user controls and dragging, etc.). I'm happy to help with code review or other questions here.<span class="line"><!---->RE #12: Those use cases seem reasonable for a powerful extension (and maybe eventually for a powerful web platform API). You'll likely need to iterate over display::Screen::GetAllDisplays() to determine the overall on-screen portion of the requested window bounds. You might want to ensure that some portion of the window's titlebar is on screen too (if the window has a titlebar for identity, user controls and dragging, etc.). I'm happy to help with code review or other questions here.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Showing the popup only when it appears at least 50% on the current displays seems reasonable to me. The question then is, what happens if bounds do not intersect 50% with the displays? Do we a) leave the popup at its current position or b) get the closest display matching and adjust to fit (similar to [1])?<span class="line"><!---->Showing the popup only when it appears at least 50% on the current displays seems reasonable to me. The question then is, what happens if bounds do not intersect 50% with the displays? Do we a) leave the popup at its current position or b) get the closest display matching and adjust to fit (similar to [1])?<!----></span><br><br>[1] <span class="line"><!---->[1] <!----></span>https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1"><!---->https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:content/browser/web_contents/web_contents_impl.cc;l=484-492;drc=28f8c4edef0c91c02a15ec3bd26f6f38a2d256ca;bpv=1;bpt=1<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!----> &lt;<!----></span>emiliapaz@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/emiliapaz@chromium.org"><!---->emiliapaz@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Tue Mar 29 15:40:06 2022<span class="line"><!---->Date: Tue Mar 29 15:40:06 2022<!----></span><br><br>[Extensions] Display window only when its bounds intersect the displays<span class="line"><!---->[Extensions] Display window only when its bounds intersect the displays<!----></span><br><br>Windows should only be displayed when they intersect the displays in a<span class="line"><!---->Windows should only be displayed when they intersect the displays in a<!----></span><br>meaningful manner (in this case, window should be visible at least 50%).<span class="line"><!---->meaningful manner (in this case, window should be visible at least 50%).<!----></span><br>Otherwise, the window will be displayed in the current default.<span class="line"><!---->Otherwise, the window will be displayed in the current default.<!----></span><br><br>This prevents for windows to be created or moved outside the displays,<span class="line"><!---->This prevents for windows to be created or moved outside the displays,<!----></span><br>and potentially been exploited.<span class="line"><!---->and potentially been exploited.<!----></span><br><br>Screencast: <span class="line"><!---->Screencast: <!----></span>https://drive.google.com/file/d/1dTJdC1OtQek4n6ok0sOfccbEr8H0Ah3U/view?usp=sharing<a class="undefined"         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the reward!<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the reward!<!----></span><br><br>The 50% check in <span class="line"><!---->The 50% check in <!----></span>#c27<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c27"><!---->#c27<!----></a> doesn't fully resolve the issue on Windows and potentially other platforms (based on the video in <span class="line"><!----> doesn't fully resolve the issue on Windows and potentially other platforms (based on the video in <!----></span>#c27<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c27"><!---->#c27<!----></a>, it seems resolved on MacOS, but I can't verify myself).<span class="line"><!---->, it seems resolved on MacOS, but I can't verify myself).<!----></span><br><br>I'll file a new report later today with updated PoCs that still repro and add a comment with the link to the new crbug.<span class="line"><!---->I'll file a new report later today with updated PoCs that still repro and add a comment with the link to the new crbug.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Issue 1301203: Security: Extension can move window off screen, user can interact with sensitive UI using keyboard without being aware
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1301203: Security: Extension can move window off screen, user can interact with sensitive UI using keyboard without being aware

        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Feb 27, 2022)
      <option value="0" selected="">

        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">

      <option value="0" selected="">

      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">

      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Feb 27, 2022)
      </option>
    <!---->
        </select>
